meanings.definition: To receive a certain number of votes in an election.
meanings.sent1: During the election, the candidate polled a high number of votes.
meanings.sent2: The politician polled well in the recent election.
meanings.sent3: The race was so close that even the last-minute polled votes made a difference.
meanings.sent4: She polled the most votes, emerging as the clear winner.
meanings.sent5: The candidate's ability to connect with voters helped him to be highly polled.

meanings.definition: To cut off the horns of an animal.
meanings.sent1: The farmer polled the cow to prevent it from harming others.
meanings.sent2: The vet polled the bull to ensure safety on the farm.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous goat kept trying to avoid being polled.
meanings.sent4: The rhinoceros looked different after being polled.
meanings.sent5: The skilled rancher expertly polled the cattle without causing them harm.

meanings.definition: To take a survey or vote.
meanings.sent1: The company polled its employees to gather feedback.
meanings.sent2: The school polled the students about their favorite subjects.
meanings.sent3: The family decided to poll on where to go for vacation.
meanings.sent4: The community was polled on their opinions about the new park.
meanings.sent5: The team captain polled the players to decide on the next game strategy.
